history.content:
You are fine as a Stat major in taking EECS126 with that background. Assuming of course, that you have completed linear algebra and multivariate calculus. You already know some things from Stat 134 but the level that you will be expected to perform in 126 will be higher. For someone with this background, taking 70 and 126 in parallel is probably fine. Your intuition for probability will build as you keep studying it. 

EDIT to Add: Of course, you should expect that 126 will challenge you as you learn. You will spend time on it. You will learn how to think differently and better. This is precisely why 126 is such a critically important course. It will *force* you to really understand probability better and this is why it is very important for people to take 189 *after* having taken 126. The fundamental understanding that 126 provides helps students understand the material in 189 much better. If taken in the reverse order, it is possible for students to develop "bad form" incomplete understandings of probability that will then need to be corrected in 126. Everyone benefits by taking courses in the correct order.  (ie. End-to-end learning is not a good idea for EECS material.)

You are fine as a Stat major in taking EECS126 with that background. Assuming of course, that you have completed linear algebra and multivariate calculus. You already know some things from Stat 134 but the level that you will be expected to perform in 126 will be higher. For someone with this background, taking 70 and 126 in parallel is probably fine. Your intuition for probability will build as you keep studying it.

I personally thought the probability background I had from CS70 and CS189 was not enough for EECS126 in the sense that I still had to spend a lot of time on the course and should have spent more time to do better. That's just one student's opinion however; Professor Sahai's answer is certainly correct.

children.subject:
@prof Sahai thank you for your response! 

@Ashwinee, could you elaborate on your opinion?  I don't consider myself to be the student Sahai was when he was an undergrad; why did you consider EE126 to be difficult even with 70 & 189?  The sequence I'm debating is Data100 & CS70 this semester, learn 70 material especially well, and then take CS170 & EE126 VS EE126 & Data100 now, then CS170 & EE127.  

Thank you!

history.content:
I'm trying to decide whether to take EE126 or push it off a semester and take CS 70 first.  I've taken Stat 134, 135 (received A-'s) and read most of How to Prove It.   Is this preparation sufficient to overcome not taking CS70?  I'd like to also take CS170, which supposedly also builds off the proof skills in CS70 as well as the graph theory.  I'm currently studying statistics entering my third year and I'd attribute my grades in stats courses more to preparation than raw probability intuition, and EE126 is supposedly much more rigorous.  Would the recommendation be to take EE126 now or wait a semester?    

Thank you!
history.subject: Appropriate Background for EE126?
